content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A conducting bar is on and perpendicular to a pair of parallel, horizontal conducting rails. The width <math alttext="w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>w</mi></mstyle></math> between the rails can be changed. The rails extend into a region where there is a uniform magnetic field of known magnitude <math alttext="B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> that is directed out of the page. The left ends of the rails extend into the magnetic field, as shown in the top view in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

The experiment is set up so that the bar is pulled to the left at constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The bar is always perpendicular to the rails as the bar moves to the left. The <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> induced in a conducting bar moving with speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> is equal to <math alttext="B L v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>v</mi></math>, where <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> is the length of the bar.

A group of students are asked to create a linear graph that can be used to experimentally calculate the constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of the bar as it is pulled to the left. In addition to the equipment described, the students are only permitted to use a voltmeter and a meterstick.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to create a linear graph that can be used to experimentally calculate the constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of the bar as it is pulled to the left. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A conducting bar is on and perpendicular to a pair of parallel, horizontal conducting rails. The width <math alttext="w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>w</mi></mstyle></math> between the rails can be changed. The rails extend into a region where there is a uniform magnetic field of known magnitude <math alttext="B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> that is directed out of the page. The left ends of the rails extend into the magnetic field, as shown in the top view in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

The experiment is set up so that the bar is pulled to the left at constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The bar is always perpendicular to the rails as the bar moves to the left. The <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> induced in a conducting bar moving with speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> is equal to <math alttext="B L v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>v</mi></math>, where <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> is the length of the bar.

A group of students are asked to create a linear graph that can be used to experimentally calculate the constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of the bar as it is pulled to the left. In addition to the equipment described, the students are only permitted to use a voltmeter and a meterstick.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to create a linear graph that can be used to experimentally calculate the constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of the bar as it is pulled to the left. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data could be graphed, and how that graph would be analyzed, to determine the constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of the bar.

The bar and rails are removed from the magnetic field. Several coils of wire, each made of <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> loops of wire of different radii <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, are placed in the magnetic field. The magnetic field is then made to vary sinusoidally with time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> according to the equation <math alttext="B equals, B sub 1, the sine of, open parenthesis, 2 pi f t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="B sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is the amplitude of the field and <math alttext="f equals 100 hertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mo lspace="0.02em" rspace="0.02em">=</mo><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Hz</mtext></math>. The maximum induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="script uppercase E sub maximum" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> is measured for each coil.
(c) A group of students is asked to experimentally determine the field amplitude <math alttext="B sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> using the coils of wire. The data recorded by the students is shown in the table.
<math alttext="r of m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="script uppercase E sub max, end sub, of V " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mi>max</mi></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="0.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.01</mn></math><math alttext="0.18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.18</mn></math><math alttext="0.02" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.02</mn></math><math alttext="0.55" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.55</mn></math><math alttext="0.03" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.03</mn></math><math alttext="1.22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.22</mn></math><math alttext="0.04" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.04</mn></math><math alttext="2.37" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.37</mn></math><math alttext="0.05" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.05</mn></math><math alttext="3.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.9</mn></math>

i. Indicate two quantities that could be graphed to produce a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="B sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.

Vertical axis: _____________          Horizontal axis: ____________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the following graph. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units.
iii. Draw the best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).

(d) Using the straight line from part (c)(iii), calculate the value of <math alttext="B sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
